ygData.subject: Re: Introducing a New Approach to Search: Novelty Search (New Paper)
ygData.msgSnippet: Mattias, Great idea to refer to the pictures.  They indeed help with this type of speculation.  You make a sound mathematical case about point distributions,

From: "Kenneth Stanley" <kstanley@...>
Subject: Re: Introducing a New Approach to Search: Novelty Search (New Paper)
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=54567749; y=oJU3NpTBG5Ha0_ZTmy3IWiKaWsKBizJOQiesU9JjjwsWU3g7Leli
X-Yahoo-Profile: kenstanley01

Mattias,

Great idea to refer to the pictures.  They indeed help with this =
type
of speculation.  You make a sound mathematical case about point
distri=
butions, yet I believe at the same time that they can also be
interpreted t=
o support my hypothesis:

You note that the walls get nearly filled close t=
o the starting
position, but that this density peters out farther away.  Ye=
t you do
not any further tackle the question of why this density is peterin=
g
out.  My hypothesis with respect to complexification ascending through
a =
set of heuristics suggests that this petering out is the key
phenomenon, an=
d that it is indicative of the fact that vast swaths of
possible trajectori=
es are never (and would never need to be) considered.

Now that I look at t=
he two graphs from novelty search, thanks to you
focusing me on them, I thi=
nk that even the difference between the two
of them provides further eviden=
ce for this view.

In both graphs, as you note, the immediately accessible =
corridors from
the starting position are filled along the walls.  These rep=
resent to
me the most trivial (linear) heuristics, i.e. "turn and run" in s=
ome
simplistic function of sensory inputs.    

Yet what's very interesting=
 is that the two mazes exhibit different
phenomena after that.  In the medi=
um map, the density even in the next
corridor decreases significantly, and =
in fact, in corridors after
that, it is extremely sparse.  This rapid decli=
ne in density indicates
that NEAT is ascending through heuristics that repr=
esent general
principles that involve the "weaving" concept needed to run t=
hrough
the maze.  Notice that it can do this because the maze is repetitiou=
s
in a way that allows a fairly compact concept to describe the solution
be=
havior.  The significant decrease in density supports the idea that
NEAT is=
 not coming close to enumerating all possible behaviors and is
rather lifti=
ng the heuristic to higher levels of generality, which
happens to be a grea=
t way to escape to novel behaviors in this maze.

However, in the hard maze=
, you see something different: Even after one
or two turns into different e=
nclosures, the density on walls remains
high.  My interpretation of this fa=
ct is that the arbitrary meandering
of this maze does not allow for a simpl=
e general heuristic to get from
one enclosure to the next, and therefore NE=
AT ends up having to go
through less heuristic-like and more enumerative-li=
ke behaviors.  In
other words, it has to learn specific directions like "go=
 straight
then turn turn then go straight then..etc.." which precludes it f=
rom
gaining an advantage with lower levels of complexity that could
describ=
e general navigation strategies.  Nevertheless, we see that in
the compartm=
ent just before the compartment with the goal, density
indeed finally decre=
ases (for example see the sparseness in the
upper-right of the right boundi=
ng wall of the maze and above the lower
wall of upper-right compartment), s=
uggesting that it is beginning to
hit on some heuristics that are general e=
ven in this more arbitrary maze.

Thus these depictions seem to support my =
overall hypothesis:  The more
regular the domain, the less density will be =
encountered over the
entire space of behaviors.   After all, what makes the=
 medium maze
"medium" for a *novelty* search?  Why should it be an "easier"=
 for a
method that is not trying to do anything in particular?  The answer =
is
that its solution involves a kind of behavioral regularity, and is
there=
fore encountered earlier as the complexity bucket fills from
bottom to top.=


Thus it appears there are again two interpretations of the result. 
When =
I see the medium map density graph, I see an analogy for any
problem where =
as soon as we find a general heuristic we begin to
escape at a rapid rate i=
gnoring vast swaths of the behavior space
(because they would be more compl=
ex to represent).  And the good news
is that most interesting problems shou=
ld have some heuristic
properties, from the regular ambulation of a virtual=
 creature to the
regular rules of a game like checkers.  Yet even in the ha=
rd maze,
some generalities (though more complex ones) do begin to take hold=
,
and density drops accordingly.  Overall, then, the equations that
guide t=
he increase in # evaluations should not increase simply
according to surfac=
e areas and open volumes.  Rather, it would depend,
as it should if novelty=
 search is to succeed, on generality.

ken


--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "=
Mattias Fagerlund" <mattias@...> wrote:
>
> Ken, 
> 
> Looking at the pictu=
re in the paper that describes where different
> novelties have ended up su=
ggests that walls get nearly completely filled
> close to the starting posi=
tion, petering out significantly further
away. 
> 
> The open areas are lig=
htly filled with novelties increasing in tight
spots
> and decreasing furth=
er from the starting position. 
> 
> Now, if we extend that behaviour to th=
e third dimension, which was where
> my reasoning started even though I was=
n't too clear about that in my
> conversations, it would appear that a (sqr=
t(X))^3 would be close to the
> expected consequence;
> 
> Walls, now areas=
, would be almost uniformly filled (increased from lines
> to ^2). Empty ar=
eas, now volumnes, would be sparsely filled (increased
> from area ^2 to vo=
lume ^3). 
> 
> That would indicate that some of the novelties would expand=
 X^(3/2) and
> some would expand X^2, which might make the resulting sum wo=
rse than
> (sqrt(X))^3.
> 
> I understand your explanation that not the ent=
ire search space is
going to
> be searched due to the complexification natu=
re of NEAT, but that doesn't
> enter into the computation if what I say abo=
ve is correct. Extending the
> current behaviour in 2D (which allready inco=
rporates the advantage you
> descrive) into 3D should look similar to the 2=
D result, and therefore
> require that many more novelties to be visited.
>=
 
> If some additional effect would occur making the 3D version look
> sign=
ificalty different from the 2D version, then all bets are off, but
> specul=
ating about that seems a wee bit... speculative?  ;)
> 
> cheers,
> mattias=
